utterances: Dad died in 1966 at the start of my fourth-grade year.
I don't remember anything about the school year except the sad way my teachers stared at me.
I didn't like it.
But rather than say anything, I tried to stay busy.

I did the same thing at home - tried my best to stay out of mama's way, hoping that I wasn't too big of a burden to her and pray nightly that God wouldn't snatch her away too because then what ever would I do?
I didn't talk much about my father in those days.
I was trying to do what everybody thought I ought to do - forget it and move on.
But on the inside, down deep where only God and dead fathers know what's in a girl's heart, I swore that one day I was going to make things right.
I'd prove all those people wrong, those people who said what a waste.
I promised I'd get that education that my father never got the chance to.
I wasn't a particularly good student, but I liked books and read a lot.
A girlfriend helped me to apply for college and to her delight, I was accepted.
Dad's GI Bill helped pay my way.
The 25th Infantry Division, my dad's unit, gave me a scholarship that helped me buy books.
I studied hard in college.
I knew dad would want me to.
It was during my freshman year of college that I began to talk to my father again.
I go on walks across the campus and tell him all about my day, how hard biology was, and did he understand anything about geology?
He never said anything, but I knew he was listening to everything I said.
I knew he overheard everything my college roommate said, too.
The worst of which was when she told the entire study room it was a damn shame her parents' tax dollars had to go to support my college education just because my father had died in that stupid war.
I wanted to cuss her back.
Instead, I simply picked up my books and said, you know what I wish, I wish I could get back every singly penny of your parents' tax dollars for one more day with my father.
My college graduation day remains one of the brightest of my life.
I was the first member of my father's family to earn a college degree.
It felt as if in some measure I'd made sure my father's death wasn't in vain.
I was finally able to let go of the childhood fury that had propelled me into an adult, hell-bent and redeeming the sense of a wrong-headed war.
I placed that anger at the altar of Panel 9 East of the Vietnam Veterans Memorial Wall during Veterans Day of 2002, my first trip to the wall.
It's a trip I make every year now.
For me, it's like a church homecoming.
It's the one place where I can gather with men and women who dedicated their youth to faithfully serving the country that called them to war.
I've come to understand that no matter how misguided a war might be a soldier's service is never a waste.
It's a sacrifice.
One for which a free people should always be grateful.
Writer Karen Spears Zacharias.

In Nicaragua, preliminary work has begun on a canal to connect the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans.
This canal will be three times the length of Panama's and will cut through forests, wetlands and a giant inland lake.
Backers say the project will create 50,000 jobs and double the size of Nicaragua's economy.
But opposition to the waterway is growing, as John Otis reports.
Just off the Pacific Coast, graders and rollers put the finishing touches on an access road that will be used to bring in heavy equipment to build the Nicaraguan canal.
Deeper, wider and longer than the Panama Canal, it's designed to handle ships that are more than four football fields in length.
The $50 billion project will require a lot of digging.
The builder is Hong Kong-based HKND Group, which is headed by Chinese entrepreneur Wang Jing.
He says it will be the largest earthmoving project in human history.
According to one newspaper estimate, enough dirt will be removed to cover Manhattan up to the 21st floor of the Empire State Building.
Engineers will also flood a vast section of jungle to form an artificial lake.
(Shouting) No al canal, no al canal.
But as Nicaraguans begin to grasp the true size and scope of the project, protests are springing up.
Demonstrators here are marching across Ometepe, a volcanic island in Lake Nicaragua that lies along the canal's proposed route.
Along the way they listen to an anti-canal anthem that blares from speakers on the back of a truck.
(SOUNDBITE OF ANTI-CANAL ANTHEM)
(Singing in foreign language).
One of the protesters is Alex Cheves, who owns a grocery store on the island.
(Foreign language spoken).

Cheves points out that under a new law, the Nicaraguan government could seize his property or any others deemed necessary for the canal and its related projects that include ports, free trade zones and golf resorts.
Government officials say that these properties will be purchased at fair prices, but the demonstrators here say they don't want to leave their homes.
(Foreign language spoken).
We are accustomed to living off the land,"" says yucca farmer Menardo Mairena, ""but if we are expropriated, we would end up in the streets.
Then there's the issue of the water surrounding Ometepe Island.
Lake Nicaragua is Central America's largest and provides drinking water to dozens of towns.
But to make way for supersized oil tankers and container ships, blueprints call for part of the lake bottom to be dredged to create a shipping lane.
The soil, rocks and muck dug up from the bottom will be used to create three more islands.
It doesn't make sense for us to lose all of that water for the purpose of the canal.
Biologist Jorge Huete is vice president of the Nicaraguan Science Academy.
He says the dredging could kick up so much sediment that it would discolor the water, lower its oxygen content and kill-off marine life.
For now, the canal is moving ahead even though an environmental impact study of the project has yet to be completed.
HKND refused NPR's request for comment.
Manuel Coronel, who heads the Nicaraguan Canal Authority, argues that the canal will be good for the environment.
He says the government will use profits from the waterway to strictly enforce green laws.
The environmental situation will be much better than it is today because today, actually, the environmental situation is deteriorating all the time because nobody takes care of it.
So we will be able to protect all that with the money.
Polls show that most Nicaraguans support the project.
